RT @SenateAgGOP STARTING SOON (10 am ET): Senate Ag Committee hearing “Examining Digital Assets: Risks, Regulation, and Innovation” WATCH LIVE >>> http://ag.senate.gov or https://www.c-span.org/video/?517737-1/commodity-futures-trading-commission-chair-testifies-regulating-cryptomarkets

We cannot fix our democracy and heal this country if we don’t have trust. We suffer from an enormous trust deficit right now. I often say the opposite of democracy is apathy. Apathy is prevalent when trust is absent. Let’s take bold action to restore trust. END

OUR OATH: When we swear oath into office, we say we “bear true faith and allegiance” to the Constitution. We state we are taking “this obligation freely, without any mental reservation.” We have no “purpose of evasion.” It’s critical to show that we are living up to this.14/15

Regardless of trust I have in many colleagues, we cannot ignore the fact that vast majority of Americans feel otherwise. Bold action to get away from whac a mole approach would reshape nature of the debate and reset the foundation upon which public service and trust rests. 13/15

There is real momentum here to address stocks in Congress. I greatly respect what some of my colleagues already proposed and support their efforts. Let’s keep working together. Urge us to consider expanding scope to Executive and Judiciary too and conflicts of interest.12/15

BAN ON CORPORATE BOARDS: Did you know Members of Congress are allowed to sit on corporate boards while still in office? Our oath to the Constitution should not be brought into question by having fiduciary duties to corporations. Let’s just cut out the ambiguity. 11/15
BAN ON OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT/INCOME: Being a Member of Congress is a full-time job. It deserves our full and undivided attention. American people want to know we are 100% focused on them. 10/15

BAN ON LOBBYING: We also don’t want Members of Congress taking actions in office that are meant to set them up with lucrative opportunities to capitalize on their connections. Creating a ban on post-Congress lobbying for profit would cut off this concern. 9/15

PUBLIC TRUST: With diversified mutual funds, the public would know exactly what gov officials know about their investments, whereas blind trusts would move the public’s knowledge further into the dark. Even Mitch McConnell advises Members to do diversified mutual funds. 8/15

MAXIMIZE TRANSPARENCY: An elegant way to avoid conflict of interest is to require investment in diversified mutual funds rather than allowing stock trades through blind trusts. This would allow maximum transparency and sunlight while still allowing investment in markets. 7/15

CONFLICT OF INTEREST: With knowledge of blind trust contents, Members could still take votes/actions that benefit them. I ask colleagues who support blind trust methods to consider requiring liquidating assets before setting up blind trust to minimize conflicts of interest. 6/15

BLIND TRUSTS AREN’T FULLY BLIND: One problem is that Congressional blind trusts don’t require Members to initially liquidate holdings and have blind trust reinvest without Members’ knowledge. As a result, Members know the initial contents of trust and get updates on trades. 5/15

STOP STOCK OWNERSHIP: Much debate so far has been about blind trusts. Blind trust is better than status quo, but it doesn’t stop individual stock ownership or trading on your behalf. It helps address insider trading concerns, but still leaves real conflicts of interest. 4/15

In same way Members of Congress should not profit on their service, we should not forget about President, Cabinet Secretary, Supreme Court Justice, etc. Right now, there are no rules stopping any of these positions from owning/trading individual stocks. This should change. 3/15

The Constitution is sacred, and any job created by the Constitution or appointed by one calls for sacred trust. But trust from American people in Gov is so low that we must make the strongest effort to restore. Trust is shaken not just by Congress, but across all government. 2/15

Piercing together scraps of fabric and clothing, the original Gee’s Bend quilters—enslaved women from Gee’s Bend in the 19th century—created abstract designs that had never before been expressed on quilts. Their work was passed down over generations, gaining national recognition.

Loretta Pettway, Lucy Mingo, & Mary Lee Bendolph made their mark on history using the quilting lineage of Boykin, AL—better known as Gee’s Bend—to establish the Freedom Quilting Bee as a way to help African American women gain economic independence in 1966. #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FLKaheaWQAU6CT8.jpg

I cosponsored @RepAndyLevin's resolution recognizing Congressional workers' right to organize.

Staffers are public servants who work tirelessly on behalf of our country and the American people. They deserve to be paid fairly and work in a safe, healthy environment. Simple.

We have an opportunity to demonstrate our values of believing in the collective voice and power of workers. We cannot stop fighting until every worker in the country can form a union, without interference, including our own employees, right here in the Congress of the U.S.

That’s why a new relief package, targeted at the small businesses most impacted by Omicron, is so critical right now. I won’t stop fighting until we get our communities the relief that they need.

As I’ve met with small business owners and local officials throughout NJ-11, all have expressed concern about the impact of Omicron on our economy and communities. I fear that, without additional assistance, many more businesses in North Jersey will be forced to close.

At the same time, Omicron has greatly impacted consumer demand for businesses centered on in-person gatherings, such as the @MayoCenter in Morristown and so many of our local restaurants, and has made it even more difficult for them to hire the workers they need.

The CARES Act and American Rescue Plan were so important during the pandemic in saving businesses across NJ-11, through  programs like the Paycheck Protection Program and Restaurant Revitalization Fund, but those crucial initiatives have now expired.

This week, I led ten of my colleagues in a letter to President Biden urging the Administration to support and help negotiate a new, targeted relief package to assist small businesses impacted by Omicron.

It’s an honor to serve as Chair of @HSGAC—I’ll continue working to deliver for Michiganders and Americans across the country.

✅Led a 2 part hearing identifying the lethal threat of violence motivated by race, religion, and political affiliation. Further examined actions needed to address domestic terrorism & violent extremism—specifically the prevalence of white supremacist, anti-government groups.

✅Secured $1 billion to help state, local, tribal, and territorial governments deter attacks from malicious cyber actors and modernize systems to protect sensitive data—including $100 million to help victims of a serious attack recover quickly.

✅Convened a hearing with experts to examine the role social media platforms play in the amplification of harmful content including domestic extremism, terrorism, and other threats to homeland security.

✅Examined how Michiganders have been affected by PFAS contamination and pressed the @DeptofDefense to be held accountable for their failure to alert servicemembers about PFAS exposure from military sites.

✅Led the 1st joint hearings after the attack on the Capitol to press for answers. Further examined what security & policy failures led to the attack by leading a bipartisan investigation.

Learn more about our findings⬇️

📺https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v3OPQSf26K0&ab_channel=HSGACDems  

📄https://www.hsgac.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/HSGAC&RulesFullReport_ExaminingU.S.CapitolAttack.pdf
✅Passed bipartisan legislation—signed into law by @POTUS—to help protect K-12 school systems from cyber-attacks.
✅Led the charge to secure critical federal resources through the American Rescue Plan to accelerate COVID vaccine distribution and support national vaccination efforts
✅Secured $500 million in funding for my bipartisan STORM Act—to help communities with flooding, shoreline erosion & rising water levels that was enacted as part of the infrastructure law.
